Mini 1825: Accountant's Bland Mafia

General Game Rules
0. Don't rules-lawyer.
1. All site-wide rules apply.
2. Don't quote private Moderator-information, even if it's not real. You can paraphrase if you want.
3. Please don't communicate privately with each other unless your role PM says you can or you're a mafia member.
4. Please be active. As a general guideline, one post every 48 hours is the bare minimum.

Night Actions
1. Submit all night actions by the deadline or I will assume you don't want to make any actions.
2. If you don't want to make any actions, PM "No Action" to me.
3. For the mafia, the latest post with a decision to kill that is bolded will be the final kill order. Remember to specify who is making the kill.

Voting, Deadlines and Death
1. You can lynch a player by getting more than half the surviving players to vote them.
2. Once a majority happens you can't unvote.
3. Everyone including the lynched player can continue posting until I post the flip.
4. I won't count a vote unless it's clear who you're voting for.
5. Use the vote/unvote tag to vote or unvote. I will not count votes or unvotes not in vote/unvote tags.
6. You can also vote No Lynch if you want.
7. I will post a vote count regularly.
8. Each game day will last two weeks. There will be no extensions of the deadline.
9. Each game night will last two days. There will be no extensions or shortening of the deadline.
10. When players die, they can't post any more. At all. There are no exceptions.

Activity
1. If you have not posted in 48 hours, I will see if you have any prods. If you do, I will replace you. If you don't I will prod you.
2. If you do not respond to a prod within 24 hours, I will replace you.
3. I may replace players at any time if I see they are just posting to avoid prods and are not really playing the game.
4. If you are not going to be able to play for large amounts of time, consider replacing out. To be honest, I don't really like players who go V/LA for long periods of time without replacing out.

Miscellaneous
1. Don't be an asshole to people. If you don't know what this rule means, either look at General Game Rule 0 or replace out.
2. Red color is my color. Please don't make posts with this color.
3. Do not use small text, invisible text, cryptography or other weird posting tricks.
4. If you want to make a public request to me(for example asking for a prod on someone), bold it so I won't miss it.
5. If you want to make a private request to me, PM me.
6. Mafia members can talk during the day.
7. There are 10 town members and 3 mafia members. No third parties or additional factions.
8. If you break any of these rules, I will kill you.
Vanilla Townie Role PM:
You are a Vanilla Townie

Abilities:
You have no abilities.

Win Condition:
You win when all threats to the town are eliminated and there is at least one town player alive.

Game Thread:
The game thread is here: [ ]

Alive
1) Comparing Realities BlueBloodedToffee
2) rb
3) Chuck

If your wondering why I'm just openily announcing this right at the start its because in my last town game it sorta came out naturally while I was sleepy in this really deep self reflective sorta conversation with another player (review My last game on the first 4 pages to see that naturally) and afterwards It helped me as I could point back to it and say; 'hey this is something I already pointed out I do, stop trying to use it as a scum tell' So.. as It kinda worked well and made others understand my thoughts sometimes I thought I'd just open with it this time.

So yeah.. thats my introduction and I hope to have a good game.

Speaking of LAMIST; the setup tells us that scum have day talk if you missed it, so please bare that in mind over the game.

This is true, I'm baiting people onto the wagon and seeing who has the worst reasons to be on the wagon. My scumread on gameplay was weak at best, I was just picking a wagon on the players currently active in the game without much regard for their actual alignment. Reasoning:

- Picking someone at random is a 75% chance that the wagon is on a town player, 25% it's on a scum player.
- If I hit a town player, I'm likely to get bad sheep (aka scum) jumping on the wagon
- If I hit a scum player, I'm likely to get good sheep (aka town) jumping on the wagon, and also some kind of chainsaw defence from scumbuddies

Either way, this is a thing that helps me and the town sort the alignments of myself, gameplay and anyone else who gets caught up in the mess. It was and is 100% bait - I think that gameplays interactions with me WERE bad but that it's too tenuous to actually wagon him all the way to a lynch, but I love me some big wagons early game because you learn a lot more than if the whole game just middles around with no clear direction. By playing such a forceful strategy, I force scum to interact with the game as well - if the scum's plan was to be lurky, they're forced to not be able to play the way they wanted. Ofc I can't know if scum wanted to play lurky or not, but if they did want to fly under the radar - they're not able to do that now.

And as far as I'm concerned, a town with any kind of direction is always going to function better than a town with NO direction.

The essence of this case is theoretically sound; Mafia players would love to be able to play as RyanK is (no contiguous thought process, no meaningful effort to actually solve the game beyond single post quotes at a time) if they could do so without being lynched. This bothers me as well, which is why I've been trying to push RyanK away from the current style in favor of one that offers more comprehensive reads that can be analyzed for motivation in greater depth. My read is still that the specific single-post quotes and things that RyanK seems to feel indicate alignment are more likely to come from Town, but it is a feature of that style that my read will be unable to progress on RyanK while it lasts, and it's not implausible to me that a Town player would find that sufficient cause to vote for RyanK--particularly after prompting RyanK for more substantive reads multiple times without success, as gameplay506 has done (736, 770, 780, 1050).
If gameplay506 is Mafia, this line of attack would most resemble a Mafia player targeting a Town player playing weakly, such that I would not expect RyanK and gameplay506 to both be Mafia.

The case on rb is not one that moves me. Many items involve associations between RyanK and rb. I feel that the awkward reactions by RyanK to rb early in the game (51, 60) that are cited are far more plausible if RyanK is Mafia and rb is Town than if they are both Mafia (RyanK seems eager to flatter rb, which doesn't seem an obvious interaction between Mafia players). Another item is that rb is taking things out of context or applying ideas inconsistently (claiming to be a likely N1 kill but wanting to explain things D2, reading me as Town now despite having a negative reaction to my first vote). I don't find these items very persuasive, and certainly not persuasive enough to override my reasons for reading rb as Town (initially this was for the way that rb helped move the game out of RVS, but I think that stronger evidence would be the way that rb shows evidence of reading the game over again starting in 659 with some read progression). While I don't agree with the case on rb, I don't feel that anything about it makes gameplay506 likely to be Mafia; it is certainly plausible to me that a Town player, particularly one focused on RyanK, would see rb reading RyanK as Town and gameplay506 as Mafia as a sign of a chainsaw defense.

As a last note, the Town reads are not greatly detailed but they are mostly consistent. I agree that pitoli is showing evidence of trying to read players, and that Naomi-Tan (now Expedience) seemed to exhibit a Town mindset when actually dealing with the game (and that opening post was NAI). The read on Saru wasn't detailed, so I'll ask about it in a separate post.

Overall, both of the major cases are unpersuasive but do not show any clear evidence that gameplay506 is not trying to read other players. They could easily come from a Town player, but do not seem particularly difficult for a Mafia player to feign. I've no objection to the reads on pitoli and Expedience. Barring something terrible in the Saru read, gameplay506 remains a Null read to me.

Hopefully the method below will be useful. It's my method of learning both mafia and chess and it has been really useful to me so far. If you ever reach a situation that wasn't covered, you're free to PM me as it could actually take forever to cover everything.

After or during a game, decide if something better could have been done if particular situation to reach your win-con. Apply it when the conditions are similar and the win-con is the same. If it ever fails you, compare the situations. If there aren't any differences between the situations, decide which course of action was better and use the course of action that is better next time.

In post 3052, RyanK wrote:Looks like an algorithm for artificial inteligence to me. I won't like my computer to start thinking and turn against me for making it do lots of work though.

Looks like a good way to fuck yourself over. What works in 9p games won't work in 32p games. What works against House won't work against Titus.

What you need to do is derive the general principle that underpins the strategy and use it. If camn fakehammers to bait mafia, don't think that fakehammering is a great move that catches mafia. It is the principle of "baiting the mafia with false information to provoke them into revealing themselves" that underpinned it. Understand this, and a lot of options will be open to you; for example, you might start a wagon on an obvious target to provoke mafia into leaping on eagerly. Or you might claim to scumread X so strongly that you'll quickhammer him during LyLo, and see who tries to set up a 1v1 between you and X in LyLo.

By thinking deeper, you will find yourself able to adapt, granting you far more versatility.

Winning at mafia has various logical underpinnings which can be measured many ways based on many variables.

One could say facetiously that it is as simple as:

1. Be good at mafia.
2. Don't be bad at mafia.

Or ... one could say it is a mixture of drawing the right alignment and having the right teammates and knowing what the optimal play is for each situation and knowing how to use any power role you might have to its optimum usefulness and being in the right place at the right time with the right teammates and being active enough but not too active and reading each and every single one of the opposing players' personalities and playing in a way that will make the greatest amount of them town read you at any given juncture and being accurate in your scumreads as well as charismatic enough to get people to sheep your reads but also nonthreatening enough to avoid nightkills so you can give town your best guesses at the most critical moments while also avoiding stepping on anyone else's toes or rubbing large personalities the wrong way regardless of your or their alignment all while following all the rules and not alienating your significant other for being on the computer or your phone too often and also being covert enough not to get the site blocked on your workplace's internet provider... and that's just scratching the surface.

There's a reason I've been playing this long.

It is incredibly interesting, imperfect yet intrinsically, intimately intricate, and impossibly, inexplicably inimitable.

It's worth studying... and studying well. It'll teach you a lot about people. It'll teach you a lot about yourself.
